original.text: Little give and go with JaeSung and Sonny. He flicks it over to DongKyung and he back flicks it into the back of the net.

sentences.notes: flick over: (공을) 가볍게 툭 쳐서 넘기다. 축구 경기 해설에 사용됨.
sentences.translation: 이재성과 손흥민 사이에 짧은 패스 주고받기가 있었어요. 이재성이 이동경에게 살짝 넘겨줬고, 이동경은 뒤로 차 넣어 골망을 흔듭니다.

original.text: There's a lot of stuff (that) you guys do, that could potentially ruin your trip.

sentences.notes: ruin your trip: 여행을 망치다.
sentences.translation: 여러분들이 하는 많은 것들이 잠재적으로 여행을 망칠 수 있어요.

original.text: I'm not going to / won't let that happen. (no way, that's not happening)

sentences.notes: let that happen: 그런 일이 일어나도록 두다/허용하다.
sentences.translation: 저는 그렇게 되도록 두지 않을 거예요.

original.text: I'm going to talk you through the signs that your trip is going to end up being a disaster so you can course correct and end up having the best visit to London ever.

sentences.notes: talk through: 자세히 설명하다, 처음부터 끝까지 논의하다. course correct: 방향을 수정하다.
sentences.translation: 저는 여러분의 여행이 결국 재앙으로 끝날 징후들을 처음부터 끝까지 설명해 드릴 거예요. 그래서 여러분이 방향을 수정하고 런던에서 최고의 방문을 할 수 있도록요.

original.text: I was willing to talk to anyone.

examples: I was totally open to chatting with anyone. We ended up talking about feeling like nobody got us and how it seemed like things were never quite right.
sentences.notes: willing to + 동사: 기꺼이 ~하다. open to + ~ing: ~에 개방적이다, ~할 의향이 있다.
sentences.translation: 저는 누구와도 기꺼이 이야기할 의향이 있었어요.

original.text: And we talked about feeling misunderstood, and that something was always off.

sentences.notes: feel misunderstood: 오해받는다고 느끼다. off: 뭔가 이상한, 잘못된.
sentences.translation: 그리고 우리는 오해받는 기분과, 항상 뭔가 잘못 흘러간다는 것에 대해 이야기했어요. (오해받고, 항상 뭔가 잘못흘러가)

original.text: My friend told me she was convinced she had a sleeping disorder, but it turned out she was just diagnosed by TikTok.

examples: She told me she was in London last year, and it turns out she happened to be staying in the same hotel as me.
I happened to see your brother at the mall yesterday.
The person who helped me happened to be a doctor, so I was really lucky.
Do you happen to know where the nearest subway station is?
sentences.notes: turn out: 결국 ~임이 드러나다, 알고 보니 ~이다. happen to v: 우연히도 ~하다, 혹시 ~에요?.
sentences.translation: 제 친구는 수면 장애가 있다고 확신했지만, 알고 보니 틱톡에 의해 진단받은 것이었어요.

original.text: It was just off of the pandemic and I had a family doctor, so I didn't really need to seek any outside help.

examples: They went straight to the beach right off of their last exam.
We're going to grab some pizza off of the game; do you want to join us?
sentences.notes: right off of: ~의 직후에. 'off of'는 'after' 또는 '~로부터'의 의미로 사용됨.
sentences.translation: 팬데믹이 막 끝난 직후였고 저는 주치의가 있었기 때문에 외부 도움을 구할 필요가 없었어요.

original.text: So it was very solitary.

examples: She has been leading a solitary life since she moved to the countryside.
He enjoys taking solitary walks in the woods every morning.
He was lonely even though he was surrounded by many people.
sentences.notes: solitary: 혼자 하는, 고립된, 단독의.
sentences.translation: 그래서 그것은 매우 고립된 일이었어요.

original.text: Sorry, I couldn't help but overhear (you), but did you say you're looking for a good hairdresser?

examples: I happened to overhear that you're going to Paris next month.
I was just passing by and I overheard you talking about your trip to Spain. How was it?
sentences.notes: couldn't help but overhear: 자신도 모르게 엿듣다. happen to overhear: 우연히 엿듣다.
sentences.translation: 죄송하지만, 저도 모르게(어쩔 수 없이) 엿듣게 되었는데, 좋은 미용사를 찾고 있다고 말씀하셨나요?

original.text: I know a great one.

sentences.notes: great one: (앞서 언급된 명사를 대신하여) 훌륭한 사람/것.
sentences.translation: 제가 아주 좋은 분을 알아요.

original.text: I was just there, and I have some great recommendations for you.

sentences.notes: recommendation: 추천. (복수형으로 자주 사용됨)
sentences.translation: 제가 방금 거기 갔다 왔는데, 당신에게 줄 좋은 추천할 것들이 있어요.

original.text: The movie was interesting, to say the least.

sentences.notes: to say the least: 말할 것도 없이, 최소한으로 말해서. (주로 언급된 것보다 훨씬 더 심하다는 것을 강조할 때 사용)
sentences.translation: 그 영화는 최소한 흥미로웠어요. (meaning it was extremely interesting)

original.text: The kids were playing in the park by themselves while their parents watched from a bench.

examples: He got a job and is now living completely on his own.
sentences.notes: by oneself: 혼자서. on one's own: 혼자 힘으로, 독립적으로.
sentences.translation: 아이들은 부모가 벤치에서 지켜보는 동안 공원에서 자기들끼리 놀고 있었어요.

original.text: I'm so stressed out, I just want to get away from everything for a while.

sentences.notes: stressed out: 스트레스를 많이 받은. get away from: ~로부터 벗어나다.
sentences.translation: 너무 스트레스 받아요. 잠시 동안 모든 것으로부터 벗어나고 싶어요.

original.text: I felt completely out of place at the party because I didn't know anyone there.

examples: Your jacket looks so in place with your outfit. (fit/go well)
sentences.notes: out of place: 제자리에 있지 않은, 어색한. in place with: ~와 잘 어울리는.
sentences.translation: 파티에서 아는 사람이 아무도 없어서 완전히 어색함(out of place)을 느꼈어요.

original.text: This is the last time we're talking about this, right?

sentences.translation: 이게 우리가 이것에 대해 이야기하는 마지막이죠, 그렇죠?

original.text: 'cause I don't want to have to remind you to clean your room every single day.

examples: 'cause I don't want to have to get on your case about cleaning your room. (잔소리하다)
'cause I don't want to have to keep after you to clean / about cleaning your room. (재촉하다)
sentences.notes: remind: 상기시키다. get on one's case about: 잔소리하다. keep after someone: 계속 재촉하다.
sentences.translation: 왜냐면 매일 당신에게 방 청소를 하라고 상기시켜야 하는 상황이 싫으니까요.

original.text: I'll get a pint of sea salt, goat milk, and caramel, please.

examples: (Can/Do I) just grab/get/take one (myself) from/out of the freezer?
sentences.notes: pint: 약 0.57리터(영국), 약 0.47리터(미국)의 액체 용량 단위. grab/get/take one: (상품을) 하나 집다/가져가다.
sentences.translation: 씨솔트, 고트밀크, 캐러멜 맛으로 1파인트 주세요.

original.text: My car could use a wash. It's all muddied up.

examples: It's covered in mud.
It's messed up with mud.
sentences.notes: could use: ~이 필요하다. all muddied up: 진흙으로 뒤덮인/엉망이 된. covered in mud: 진흙으로 덮인. messed up with mud: 진흙으로 엉망이 된.
sentences.translation: 제 차는 세차가 필요해요. 흙으로 완전히 엉망진창이에요.

original.text: I could really use a strong cup of coffee right now, I'm so sleepy.

examples: Right about now, I could really use a cup of coffee.
sentences.notes: could really use: 정말로 ~이 필요하다. (강조)
sentences.translation: 지금 당장 진한 커피 한 잔이 정말 필요해요, 너무 졸려요.

original.text: I'm down for some pizza right now.

examples: It's been a long day. I'm down for a quiet evening at home.
We're heading to the beach. Are you down for it?
sentences.notes: down for: ~을 할 의향이 있는, ~에 동의하는 (Focus on agreement/joining)
sentences.translation: 지금 피자 좋아요. (피자 먹을 의향 있어요.)

original.text: I've got my alarm set for 7 a.m.

examples: My alarm is set for 7 a.m.
I set my alarm for 7 a.m.
I set the meeting for 2 p.m. next Tuesday.
sentences.notes: set (something) for (time): (시간을) ~로 맞추다/정하다.
sentences.translation: 저는 알람을 아침 7시로 맞춰놨어요.

original.text: The alarm clock went off at 6 a.m., so I had to wake up.

examples: My alarm always goes off at six during the week. I set it (my alarm) for six.
A car alarm went off in the middle of the night and woke everyone up.
I don't know what set off the fire alarm.
I don't know why the fire alarm went off.
sentences.notes: go off: (알람, 폭탄 등이) 울리다, 터지다. set off: (경보기 등을) 울리게 하다.
sentences.translation: 알람 시계가 아침 6시에 울려서, 저는 일어나야 했어요.

original.text: I put it on for six.

examples: I put on my alarm for six.
sentences.notes: put on one's alarm: 알람을 맞추다. (구어체 표현)
sentences.translation: 저는 그것(알람)을 6시로 맞췄어요.

original.text: The power went out for an hour during the storm.

examples: The campfire went out completely while we were sleeping, so we had to restart it this morning.
sentences.notes: go out: (불, 전기가) 나가다, 꺼지다.
sentences.translation: 폭풍이 오는 동안 전기가 한 시간 동안 나갔어요.

original.text: Did you hear that Sarah and Tom are finally going out?

examples: They make a cute couple.
sentences.notes: go out: 사귀다. make a cute couple: 귀여운 커플이다.
sentences.translation: 사라와 톰이 드디어 사귄다는 소식 들었어?

original.text: You should probably throw out that milk; it smells like it's gone bad / spoiled.

sentences.notes: throw out: 버리다. go bad/spoil: (음식이) 상하다.
sentences.translation: 그 우유는 아마 버려야 할 것 같아요. 상한 냄새가 나요.

original.text: She kept cutting me off every time I tried to speak.

examples: I was talking to my friend when a stranger cut in to ask for directions. (친구랑 얘기 중에 누가 끼어듬)
sentences.notes: cut off: (말을) 자르다, 중단시키다. cut in: 끼어들다, 방해하다.
sentences.translation: 제가 말하려고 할 때마다 그녀는 계속 제 말을 잘랐어요.

original.text: Even if the most important information is in the second part of the sentence-the part about the stranger cutting in-it's much more natural to set the scene/background first, then the event.

examples: We were having dinner when the lights went out. (식사중 불나감)
I was taking a shower when the phone rang. (샤워중 전화옴)
sentences.notes: set the scene: 배경/상황을 설정하다. 'was ~ing when' 패턴은 진행 중인 행동(배경) 중에 새로운 사건이 발생했음을 나타냅니다.
sentences.translation: 가장 중요한 정보가 문장의 두 번째 부분, 즉 낯선 사람이 끼어드는 부분에 있더라도, 상황/배경을 먼저 설정한 다음 사건을 설명하는 것이 훨씬 더 자연스럽습니다.

original.text: Ugh, I can't believe I just spilled my coffee all over my new shirt. I feel so dumb.

sentences.notes: spill: 쏟다. all over: 온통 ~에.
sentences.translation: 아, 내가 새 셔츠에 커피를 다 쏟았다니 믿을 수가 없어. 너무 바보 같아.

original.text: Oh, don't worry about it at all. If it makes you feel better, I walked out of my house this morning with my shirt on backward.

examples: I can't believe I wore my hoodie backward all day.
I can't believe I put my hoodie on backward all day.
sentences.notes: don't worry about it at all: 전혀 걱정하지 마세요. make you feel better: 기분이 나아지게 하다. on backward / wear backward / put on backward: 뒤집어 입은 채로, 거꾸로 입다.
sentences.translation: 아, 전혀 걱정하지 마세요. 그게 당신 기분을 낫게 해준다면, 저는 오늘 아침에 셔츠를 뒤집어 입고 집을 나섰어요.

original.text: We went to the beach after you took me to that one beach, I kept going back.

examples: We went to a café, walked around a bit. Drove around a bit. We walked down the main strip.
sentences.notes: keep going back: 계속 돌아가다, 계속 방문하다. walk/drive around a bit: 좀 걸어/운전해 다니다. walk down the main strip: 중심 거리를 걸어 내려가다.
sentences.translation: 당신이 나를 그 해변에 데려다준 후에, 저는 계속 (그곳으로) 돌아갔어요.

original.text: I'm pretty full, so I'm going to pass on dessert tonight.

examples: Please pass on this message to your manager.
sentences.notes: pass on: ~을 사양하다, ~을 거절하다. (메시지 등을) 전달하다.
sentences.translation: 배가 꽤 불러서 오늘 밤 디저트는 사양할게요.

original.text: You can leave out the fresh herbs if you don't have any.

examples: I'm sorry, I think I left out a key ingredient in the recipe.
We decided to leave out a few minor steps to finish the project faster.
sentences.notes: leave out: ~을 빼다, 생략하다.
sentences.translation: 신선한 허브가 없다면 빼도 돼요.

original.text: We missed out on the early bird special at the restaurant because we were running late.

examples: Looking at these old family photos, it makes me sad to realize how much I missed out on you growing up.
sentences.notes: miss out on: ~을 놓치다, ~에 참여하지 못하다.
sentences.translation: 늦어서 레스토랑의 얼리버드 스페셜을 놓쳤어요.

original.text: We had to wait until the fog cleared up / lifted to see the mountain view.

examples: We should stop and wait for the fog to clear up.
I hope the weather/sky/rain clears up before the game starts.
The fog finally lifted.
sentences.notes: clear up / lift: (안개, 날씨 등이) 걷히다, 개다.
sentences.translation: 산의 풍경을 보기 위해 안개가 걷힐 때까지 기다려야 했어요.

original.text: The whole play was a little too serious for me, but the main character's super campy monologues saved it.

sentences.notes: campy: 과장되고 우스꽝스러운, 연극적인. monologue: 독백.
sentences.translation: 연극 전체가 저에게는 좀 너무 진지했지만, 주연 배우의 매우 우스꽝스러운(과장되고 연극적인) 독백(campy monologues)이 살렸어요.

original.text: The dessert is just so good. I'm going back for seconds / I'm getting seconds.

sentences.notes: go back for seconds / get seconds: (음식의) 두 번째 접시를 먹다, 두 그릇째 먹다.
sentences.translation: 이 디저트 정말 맛있네요. 한 접시 더 먹어야겠어요. (한접시 더해야것어)

original.text: I asked for a small portion of the pasta. Too much hurts my stomach.

sentences.notes: portion of: ~의 1인분. hurt one's stomach: 속을 아프게 하다.
sentences.translation: 파스타는 적은 양(small portion)으로 달라고 했어요. 너무 많이 먹으면 속이 안 좋아(hurts my stomach).

original.text: The majority of the homes were built throughout the 70s and the 80s with the large lots.

examples: and with quiet streets, with all of them being (tree) lined with mature trees and a very quick commute to downtown Calgary, coupled/along with your close proximity to the mountains, Dalhousie is still a community that is highly regarded as one of the top in northwest Calgary.
sentences.notes: large lot: 넓은 부지. line with: ~으로 줄지어 있다. coupled/along with: ~와 더불어, ~에 곁들여. close proximity: 매우 가까움 (for emphasis). highly regarded as: ~로 높이 평가받는.
sentences.translation: 대부분의 주택은 70년대와 80년대에 걸쳐 넓은 부지(large lots)와 함께 지어졌습니다.

original.text: I wouldn't say they are typical, but the fact that they happen at all is still a problem.

examples: If you need help at all, just give me a call.
The only reason I took that terrible job at all was so I could pay off my student loans.
sentences.notes: at all: (부정문/의문문/조건문에서) 조금이라도, 전혀. (강조)
sentences.translation: 그것들이 일반적이라고 말할 수는 없지만, 조금이라도 발생한다는 사실 자체가 여전히 문제입니다.

original.text: The new cafe is good, but I wouldn't (go so far as to) say it's the best in the city.

examples: The movie was good, but I wouldn't (go so far as to) say it was a masterpiece.
sentences.notes: go so far as to say: ~라고까지 말하다. (자신이 생각하는 한계를 넘어서는 표현임을 나타냄)
sentences.translation: 새 카페는 좋지만, 시내에서 최고라고 할 정도까지(~라고할 정도까진) 말하지는 않겠어요.

original.text: I can't believe you went that far! Did you really tell your boss that he was wrong?

examples: I agree with you that the movie was a bit slow, but I wouldn't go that far and say it was the worst movie ever.
sentences.notes: go that far: 그렇게까지 하다. (주로 놀라움이나 과도함에 대한 반응을 나타냄)
sentences.translation: 네가 그렇게까지 했다니 믿을 수가 없어! 네 상사에게 그가 틀렸다고 정말 말했니?

original.text: That's why we focus (a lot of our attention in the work that we do) on helping employers understand how we can make those positive changes in those cultures.

examples: That's why we focus on helping employers understand how to make positive changes to their company culture.
So we're mainly focused on helping employers make their company cultures better.
sentences.notes: focus on + ~ing / 명사: ~에 집중하다.
sentences.translation: 그렇기 때문에 우리는 고용주들이 그러한 문화에서 어떻게 긍정적인 변화를 만들 수 있는지 이해하도록 돕는 데 (우리가 하는 일에서 많은 관심을) 집중합니다.

original.text: I find myself checking my phone a lot as I go through my day.

examples: I was so busy as I went through my day yesterday that I didn't have a minute to eat.
I'm sure you will feel more relaxed as you go through your day tomorrow.
sentences.notes: find oneself ~ing: 자신도 모르게 ~하고 있음을 알게 되다. as one goes through one's day: 하루를 보내는 동안.
sentences.translation: 하루를 보내는 동안 휴대폰을 많이 확인하는 제 자신을 발견해요.

original.text: You'll have plenty of time for this during your day.

examples: I'll be in meetings throughout the day. (emphasizes the entire duration)
sentences.notes: plenty of time: 충분한 시간. during your day: 하루 일과 중에. throughout the day: 하루 종일, 온종일.
sentences.translation: 하루 일과 중에 이것을 할 충분한 시간이 있을 거예요.

original.text: (looking at the inside of the wall) This is plaster seeping/coming through, but you can see there's no signs of mold or anything like that.

examples: And then on the other side of the wall is a plaster.
So that's why I don't want to take down the plaster because it looks good.
sentences.notes: seep through / come through: 스며 나오다. plaster: 회벽, 석고. take down: 철거하다, 제거하다. like that: 그와 같은 것.
sentences.translation: 이것은 석회가 스며 나오거나 있는 것이지만, 곰팡이나 그와 같은 것의 징후는 없음을 볼 수 있습니다.

original.text: My dad's going to come over.

examples: Also, shout out to my dad for helping me with this.
We were able to get the living room done in one day because he came over.
sentences.notes: come over: (집에) 방문하다, 오다. shout out to: ~에게 감사나 인사를 표하다. get something done: ~을 끝내다.
sentences.translation: 아빠가 오실 거예요.

original.text: But he's also going to help me with this big picture window right here.

examples: I'm taking both of these windows out and I'm adding a 60x60 window.
I'm taking out both of these windows and putting in a 60x60 window.
sentences.notes: picture window: 전망용 대형 창문, 통창. take out: 제거하다. add/put in: 추가하다, 설치하다.
sentences.translation: 하지만 그는 또한 바로 여기 있는 이 큰 통창도 저를 도와줄 거예요.

original.text: Here's the wallpaper I ordered for the bathroom. It's floral and it has a black backdrop which I think will go well with the claw foot tub and the vanity.

examples: Here's the wallpaper I ordered for the bathroom. It's got a floral design with a black background, which I think will look nice with the claw foot tub and the vanity.
sentences.notes: backdrop/background: 배경. go well with / look nice with: ~와 잘 어울리다. claw foot tub: 발 달린 욕조. vanity: 화장대.
sentences.translation: 이것은 제가 욕실용으로 주문한 벽지입니다. 꽃무늬이고 검은색 배경을 가지고 있는데, 이것이 발 달린 욕조, 세면대와 잘 어울릴 것 같아요.

original.text: So, I'll put all this up all the way around the bathroom aside from on the ceiling.

examples: So, I'll be putting this up all over the bathroom except for the ceiling.
We are going to hang the wallpaper in the living room together. (Put up the wallpaper)
sentences.notes: put up all the way around / put up all over: ~의 전체에 걸쳐 설치하다/붙이다. aside from / except for: ~을 제외하고. put up / hang: (벽지, 그림 등을) 걸다, 붙이다, 설치하다.
sentences.translation: 그래서 천장을 제외하고 욕실 전체를 빙 둘러 이것을 붙일 거예요.

original.text: We can put you up for the night if you miss the last bus.

sentences.notes: put someone up: ~에게 숙소를 제공하다, 재워주다.
sentences.translation: 막차를 놓치면 하룻밤 재워줄 수 있어요.

original.text: Now I can tell. I'm slowly getting the hang of the subtle differences between I get it and I got it.

sentences.notes: get the hang of: ~의 요령을 터득하다, ~에 익숙해지다.
sentences.translation: 이제 알겠어요. 'I get it'과 'I got it' 사이의 미묘한 차이를 천천히 익히고 있어요.

original.text: Do you guys take old tires for disposal? Remove the tires from the rims and take the rubber part of the tire for disposal.

examples: Can I leave my old tires here for disposal?
If you decide to take the job, there will be a company car at your disposal.
The research facility had all the latest technology at its disposal to conduct the experiments.
sentences.notes: for disposal: 폐기 처리를 위해. remove from the rims: 휠에서 분리하다. at one's disposal: ~의 마음대로 사용할 수 있는.
sentences.translation: 폐기를 위해 헌 타이어를 받으시나요? 타이어를 휠에서 분리하고 타이어의 고무 부분만 폐기 처리해 주세요.

original.text: How much would it cost to get my wheel covers swapped out and dispose of the old tires?

examples: Can you take the wheel covers off my summer tires and put them on my winter tires?
Could you swap/switch the wheel covers from my old tires to the new ones?
sentences.notes: wheel cover: 휠 커버. swap out / swap/switch from A to B: 교체하다, A에서 B로 바꾸다. take off: 벗기다. put on: 끼우다, 장착하다.
sentences.translation: 휠 커버를 교체하고 헌 타이어를 폐기하는 데 비용이 얼마나 들까요?

original.text: Can you please check the battery and engine oil as well? It's been a while since I replaced them.

examples: How much is a standard oil change here?
Then please take a look and replace them if necessary
sentences.notes: check the battery and engine oil: 배터리와 엔진 오일을 확인하다. replace: 교체하다. standard oil change: 일반적인 오일 교환. take a look: 살펴보다.
sentences.translation: 배터리와 엔진 오일도 확인해 주시겠어요? 교체한 지 꽤 되었어요.

original.text: I can't be bothered to get dressed and head out into the cold.

examples: I couldn't be bothered to move again, even if they offered me twice the salary.
I couldn't be bothered to argue with him about it; he's always right in his own mind.
I was going to clean up, but I just couldn't be bothered so I left the dishes in the sink.
I could have tried to fix the broken shelf, but in the end, I couldn't be bothered and just threw it out instead.
sentences.notes: can't/couldn't be bothered to + 동사: ~할 마음이 생기지 않는다, ~하는 게 귀찮다.
sentences.translation: 옷을 입고 추위 속으로 나갈 엄두가 나지 않아요.

original.text: I'd rather he didn't know.

examples: I'd rather you didn't bring up the salary issue.
sentences.notes: I'd rather + Someone + 과거 동사: (다른 사람의 행동에 대한) 바람/선호를 표현할 때 (My preference for Your action => past tense)
sentences.translation: 저는 그가 모르는 편이 더 좋아요.

original.text: I don't want to mess up the surprise.

sentences.notes: mess up: 망치다, 엉망으로 만들다.
sentences.translation: 저는 서프라이즈를 망치고 싶지 않아요.

original.text: Look, I'd rather not (say).

examples: I'd rather not go into that much detail. It was a private matter.
sentences.notes: I'd rather not (say): (자신의 행동에 대해) ~하지 않는 것이 낫다. (Same Subject: talking about me => present)
sentences.translation: 보세요, 저는 (말하고) 싶지 않아요.

original.text: This is how I know my mother best.

sentences.notes: This is how I know someone best: 이것이 내가 가장 잘 아는/익숙한 그 사람의 모습이다.
sentences.translation: 이게 제가 아는 울 엄마의 모습이죠.

original.text: Hey, I know it's only two minutes before close, but can I place an order?

sentences.notes: before close: 마감/폐점 2분 전. place an order: 주문하다.
sentences.translation: 저기요, 마감 2분 전인 건 알지만, 주문해도 될까요?

original.text: I just got the package (that) the tracking said (it) was lost last week! I'm not going to complain; better late than never.

examples: The package I thought was lost last week finally showed up! Better late than never.
sentences.notes: better late than never: 늦더라도 안 하는 것보다 낫다. show up: 나타나다, 도착하다.
sentences.translation: 지난주에 추적에서 분실되었다고 했던 소포를 방금 받았어요! 불평하지 않을 거예요. 안 하는 것보다는 늦게라도 하는 것이 낫죠.

original.text: We were going to go hiking, but I didn't feel up to it after staying up so late last night.

examples: Do you feel up to meeting for coffee later, or are you still recovering from the cold?
She isn't feeling up to the presentation today because she's got a nasty cold.
I'm not really up for going out tonight.
sentences.notes: feel up to + 명사/동명사: ~을 할 기분/힘이 되다, ~을 하고 싶다. (Focus on desire/energy). not really up for: ~할 마음이 내키지 않는.
sentences.translation: 하이킹을 가려고 했지만, 어젯밤에 너무 늦게까지 깨어 있었더니 그럴 기분이 아니었어요.

original.text: My sister's coming to pick us up, so we wouldn't have to worry about driving tonight.

examples: The restaurant closes late, so we wouldn't have to rush off right after dinner. We can take our time.
Since I already paid for the streaming service, we wouldn't have to buy the movie separately.
sentences.notes: pick up: (차로) 태우러 가다. wouldn't have to: ~할 필요가 없을 것이다. rush off: 서둘러 떠나다. take one's time: 시간을 여유롭게 쓰다.
sentences.translation: 언니가 우리를 태우러 올 거라서 오늘 밤 운전에 대해 걱정할 필요가 없을 거예요.

original.text: It's so nice not to have to park my SUV on the road.

examples: I'll be able to park it on this parking pad during the winter, so I won't have to worry about getting hit by the snowplow.
sentences.notes: not to have to: ~할 필요가 없다. parking pad: 주차 공간. won't have to worry about: ~에 대해 걱정할 필요가 없을 것이다.
sentences.translation: SUV를 길가에 주차할 필요가 없어서 정말 좋아요.

original.text: We have the frame (all) built out for this area right here.

examples: So, now we're going to see if it fits up there good/well. (finish up, get it done)
sentences.notes: build out: ~을 만들다, 완성하다. fit up: (장소 등에) 장비를 갖추다, 맞추다.
sentences.translation: 우리는 바로 이 영역에 대한 프레임을 (모두) 완성했습니다.

original.text: My windshield washer fluid is running out too fast. It's going down too fast.

sentences.notes: run out / go down: 바닥나다, 고갈되다.
sentences.translation: 제 앞 유리 와셔액이 너무 빨리 바닥나고 있어요.

original.text: We have so much stuff piling up in the garage that we can't find anything.

examples: There is so much stuff here.
sentences.notes: pile up: 쌓이다. so much stuff: 매우 많은 물건.
sentences.translation: 차고에 물건이 너무 많이 쌓여서 아무것도 찾을 수가 없어요.

original.text: He was disappointed, but he quickly brushed the failure off and started preparing for the next competition.

examples: She was able to brush his sarcastic remarks off without getting angry.
She just shrugged off the rumors about her.
I couldn't shake off the weird feeling I had about that house.
They just brushed the rumors off, so the gossip died down eventually.
It's just a small mistake; you need to brush it off and keep working.
sentences.notes: brush/shake off / shrug off: (걱정, 문제 등을) 떨쳐내다, 대수롭지 않게 여기다. die down: (소문, 감정 등이) 사그라지다.
sentences.translation: 그는 실망했지만, 재빨리 그 실패를 떨쳐내고 다음 대회를 준비하기 시작했어요.

original.text: I think the comments kind of eliminate/nullify each other, right?

sentences.notes: eliminate/nullify each other: 서로 상쇄하다, 무효화하다.
sentences.translation: 댓글들이 서로 상쇄되는(eliminate/nullify each other) 것 같아요, 그렇죠?

original.text: Because the complaint is MLS defending, but as you just said, some could go in a top five league and still have success.

examples: Wasn't he a golden boot winner in the Premier League?
So, it's not as if(though) he hasn't shown that he can score at the same kind of rate at other levels in other competitions and for other teams. (He has totally shown that) (~인건 아니야. 이중 부정)
sentences.notes: it's not as if(though) ~: ~인 것은 아니다. (반대를 강하게 부정하며 주장을 펼 때 사용)
sentences.translation: 왜냐하면 불만은 MLS 수비력에 있지만, 방금 당신이 말했듯이, 일부는 상위 5개 리그에 가서도 성공할 수 있기 때문이죠.

original.text: It's not as if we haven't tried to fix the car; we took it to three different mechanics already.

examples: We should just talk to her. It's not as if she's going to bite us.
It's not as though they're poor; they just choose to be careful with their money.
You don't need to dress up so much. It's not as though we're meeting the Queen!
sentences.notes: it's not as if(though) ~: ~인 것은 아니다. (상황을 완화시키거나 반박할 때 사용)
sentences.translation: 우리가 차를 고치려고 노력하지 않은 건 아니에요. 이미 세 명의 다른 정비사에게 가져갔었어요.

original.text: Hey, chill out! The bus will be here in a minute.

sentences.notes: chill out: 진정하다, 긴장을 풀다.
sentences.translation: 야, 진정해! 버스 곧 올 거야.

original.text: We need someone who can hit the ground running.

sentences.notes: hit the ground running: 즉시/시작부터 효과적으로 일하다. (새로운 직장이나 프로젝트에서)
sentences.translation: 우리는 즉시 효과적으로 일을 시작할 수 있는 사람이 필요해요.

original.text: I dropped off this morning for a tire change. I'm just calling to check on the progress.

examples: When can I expect (it) to be ready (for pickup)?
How much longer until it's done? If it's quick, I'll stay.
sentences.notes: drop off: (물건/사람을) 내려주다, 맡기다. check on the progress: 진행 상황을 확인하다. expect to be ready: 준비가 완료될 것을 예상하다.
sentences.translation: 오늘 아침 타이어 교체를 위해 차를 맡겼어요. 진행 상황을 확인하려고 전화했습니다.

original.text: I just stopped by on my way.

examples: I was in the area, so I thought I'd stop by.
sentences.notes: stop by: 잠깐 들르다. in the area: 이 근처에.
sentences.translation: 오는 길에 잠깐 들렀어요.

original.text: How's it coming (along)? Is it almost done?

examples: If it's not going to take too long, I'll just wait here. How much longer will it be?
sentences.notes: How's it coming (along)?: (진행 상황을 물을 때) 어떻게 되어가요? (How's it going? 은 안부를 물을 때) How much longer will it be?: 얼마나 더 걸릴까요?
sentences.translation: 어떻게 돼가고 있어요? 거의 다 됐나요?

original.text: Can you scrape out the coconut meat for me? / Can you scoop out the flesh for me?

examples: Could you cut this open so I can eat the soft meat inside?
Could you cut it in half so I can get to the meat?
sentences.notes: scrape out / scoop out: (내용물을) 긁어내다, 파내다. cut open: 베어 열다. get to the meat: 속살에 닿다/도달하다.
sentences.translation: 코코넛 속살을 좀 긁어/파내 줄 수 있나요? (코코넛 과육 좀 긁어줘)

original.text: When we went camping, we just ate off the pot we cooked the stew in.

examples: My brother always tries to eat off my plate, which drives me crazy.
They didn't have enough plates, so a few of us had to eat off napkins.
sentences.notes: eat off (something): ~에서 음식을 먹다. drive someone crazy: ~를 미치게 만들다, 짜증나게 하다.
sentences.translation: 캠핑 갔을 때, 우리는 스튜를 끓인 냄비에서 그냥 먹었어요.

original.text: I gotta go run to burn/work off all the pizza I ate last night.

sentences.notes: burn off / work off: (칼로리 등을) 운동으로 소모시키다.
sentences.translation: 어젯밤에 먹은 피자를 모두 소모시키기 위해 운동하러 가야 해요.

original.text: This hotel really spoiled me with their service. Nothing else seems good enough anymore.

sentences.notes: spoil with: ~으로 (너무 잘해줘서) 버릇없게 만들다, 기준을 높이다. not seem good enough anymore: 더 이상 충분히 좋게 보이지 않다.
sentences.translation: 이 호텔 서비스가 저를 정말 버릇없게 만들었어요. 이제 다른 어떤 것도 충분히 좋게 보이지 않네요.

original.text: I get to travel for work, which is awesome.

examples: Last night, I finally got to see my favorite band perform live. It was incredible! (Opportunity)
We get to / can leave an hour early today because we finished the project ahead of schedule! (Permission/Privilege)
Since I became a manager, I get to / can (both okay here) choose my own working hours. (Privilege)
We got to 위.갓.투. see the new car prototype earlier. (미리 볼 기회가 생겨서 좋았어/운이 좋았어)
We were able to see the new car prototype earlier. (미리 볼 수 있는 여건/능력이 되었어)
We've got to 위브가러~ drive the car before we order it. (Obligation)
sentences.notes: get to + 동사: ~할 기회/특권을 얻다. (긍정적 의미) have got to (gotta): ~해야 한다. (의무)
sentences.translation: 저는 일 때문에 여행할 기회/특권을 얻어요. 정말 멋지죠.

original.text: She was worried about presenting in English, but she absolutely pulled it off.

examples: We were worried about the deadline, but we got it done on time.
She absolutely nailed it.
sentences.notes: pull off: (어려운 일을) 해내다, 성공시키다. (Focuses on difficulty, overcoming a challenge),  nail it: 완벽하게 해내다. get it done: 끝내다.
sentences.translation: 그녀는 영어로 발표하는 것에 대해 걱정했지만, 그것을 멋지게 해냈어요.

original.text: We need to pull off the highway at the next exit for gas.

examples: The driver had to quickly pull over when the tire blew out.
sentences.notes: pull off: (도로 등에서) 벗어나다. at the next exit: 다음 출구에서. pull over: (차를) 길가에 대다. blow out: (타이어가) 터지다.
sentences.translation: 주유를 위해 다음 출구에서 고속도로를 빠져나가야 해요.

original.text: This type of thing used to throw me, but I'm older now, I don't let it get to me so much.

examples: I just don't take it seriously anymore.
sentences.notes: throw (someone): ~를 당황하게 하다. let it get to me: ~때문에 속상해하다/신경 쓰다. don't take it seriously anymore: 더 이상 심각하게 받아들이지 않다.
sentences.translation: 이런 종류의 일은 예전에는 저를 당황하게 만들었지만, 이제 나이가 들어서 그것에 크게 신경 쓰지 않아요.

original.text: Do I make myself clear?

examples: She tried hard to make herself clear to the customer who didn't speak much English.
I thought I had made my intentions clear, but apparently, there was still some confusion about the project.
sentences.notes: make oneself clear: 자신의 의사/뜻을 명확하게 하다. make intentions clear: 의도를 명확히 하다.
sentences.translation: 제 말이 명확한가요? (내 뜻이 분명한가요?)

original.text: How has your commute been lately?

examples: How's the travel to work been lately?
How long have you been spending on your commute recently?
Is your trip to the office dragging on lately?
sentences.notes: commute / travel to work / trip to the office: 통근, 출퇴근. drag on: 지루하게 계속되다.
sentences.translation: 요즘 출퇴근은 어땠어요?

original.text: I'm happy with our decision, but I want to leave the floor open in case anyone has any objections.

examples: After the presentation, the CEO left the floor open for a short Q&A session.
sentences.notes: leave the floor open: 발언 기회를 주다, 토론의 여지를 남겨두다.
sentences.translation: 저는 우리의 결정에 만족하지만, 혹시 반대 의견이 있는 분이 있을까 봐 발언 기회를 열어두고 싶어요.

original.text: Her diamond necklace for the casual dinner party felt a little over the top.

sentences.notes: over the top: 지나친, 과장된.
sentences.translation: 캐주얼한 저녁 식사 파티에 그녀의 다이아몬드 목걸이는 약간 지나쳤다고 느껴졌어요.

original.text: Only immediate family was present at the small, intimate wedding ceremony.

sentences.notes: immediate family: 직계 가족. intimate: 친밀한,사적인,(분위기가) 아늑한.
sentences.translation: 작고 친밀한 결혼식에는 직계 가족만 참석했습니다.

original.text: So that's what was going on all along!

examples: She acted surprised when the secret was revealed, but I think she knew about it all along.
They realized the missing keys had been in the bottom of her purse all along.
sentences.notes: all along: 처음부터, 내내. what was going on: 무슨 일이 일어나고 있었는지.
sentences.translation: 그래서 내내 무슨 일이 일어나고 있었던 건지 알겠어요!

original.text: I accidentally bleached my faded jeans even more.

examples: She prefers the look of distressed denim over brand-new, dark-wash jeans.
We're seeing a lot of high-end brands selling heavily distressed denim this season.
She always looks great in her vintage denim shorts.
sentences.notes: bleach: 표백하다. faded jeans: 물 빠진 청바지. distressed denim: 낡은 느낌을 준 데님. dark-wash jeans: 어두운 색 청바지.
sentences.translation: 실수로 물 빠진 청바지를 더 많이 표백했어요.

original.text: He changes into his overalls before he clocks in for his shift at the factory.

examples: I need a new pair of ripped jeans for the concert.
sentences.notes: overalls: 작업복, 멜빵바지. clocks in: 출근 시간을 기록하다.
sentences.translation: 그는 공장에서 교대 근무를 위해 출근(clocks in)하기 전에 작업복(overalls)으로 갈아입어요.

original.text: I packed/put in/threw in five pairs of socks when I was packing.

sentences.notes: pack/put in/throw in: (짐을) 챙겨 넣다.
sentences.translation: 짐을 쌀 때 양말 다섯 켤레를 챙겨 넣었어요.

original.text: I need a new pair of glasses. - I gotta get new glasses.

sentences.notes: I gotta get new glasses: 'I have got to get new glasses'의 구어체 축약형. (Very casual, dropping 'a pair of')
sentences.translation: 새 안경이 필요해요.

original.text: I tried to convince Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson to just give me the money they would've spent on my meal instead, because there was a lot I could do with that kind of cash.

examples: I ended up taking the bus, so I was able to save the time I would've wasted looking for parking.
They canceled the wedding, which was probably a good thing because they didn't have to deal with the debt they would've piled up from the party.
She chose to do the project herself, meaning the company kept the profit they would've paid out to an external contractor.
sentences.notes: would've + p.p.: ~했을 것이다. (과거에 일어나지 않은 일에 대한 가정) could do with that kind of cash: 그 정도 현금으로 할 수 있는 일이 많다.
sentences.translation: 저는 제퍼슨 씨 부부에게 대신 제 식사비로 썼을 돈을 그냥 저에게 달라고 설득하려 했어요. 왜냐하면 그 정도 현금으로는 제가 할 수 있는 일이 많았기 때문이죠.

original.text: Honestly I just loved the opportunity to go down there and pitch myself, and get out of my comfort zone.

examples: Obviously, I don't know that area, so I'm so happy for Chelsea and Mary to both get it. (그것을 얻다)
It makes sense to go to them. But, you know, I'll get the next one.
sentences.notes: pitch oneself: 자신을 어필하다/홍보하다. get out of one's comfort zone: 안락한 영역을 벗어나다. make sense to: ~하는 것이 합리적이다.
sentences.translation: 솔직히 저는 그곳에 가서 저 자신을 어필하고, 안락한 영역을 벗어날 기회가 좋았어요.

original.text: I just started here. I wasn't really expecting to get the 30 million dollar listing.

examples: But at least they know I'm ready to play and I'm going to put my best foot forward and come prepared.
sentences.notes: expecting to get: ~을 얻기를 예상하다. ready to play: 준비가 되다, 참여할 준비가 되다. put one's best foot forward: 최선을 다하다, 좋은 인상을 주려 노력하다. come prepared: 준비된 상태로 오다.
sentences.translation: 저는 여기서 막 시작했어요. 3천만 달러짜리 매물을 따낼 것이라고는 정말 예상하지 못했어요.

original.text: He worked on that project for six months straight without a break. Did he get a promotion?

examples: Would you expect otherwise? (당연쓰)
sentences.notes: straight: 연속으로, 끊임없이. Would you expect otherwise?: 당연히 그렇지 않겠어요? (긍정적 대답을 유도하는 반문)
sentences.translation: 그는 쉬지 않고 6개월 연속으로 그 프로젝트를 진행했어요. 승진했나요?

original.text: The new intern is eager to learn, but honestly, he needs a whole lot of supervision right now.

sentences.notes: eager to learn: 배우고자 열망하는. a whole lot of: 엄청나게 많은. supervision: 감독, 관리.
sentences.translation: 새 인턴은 배우고자 하는 열의가 있지만, 솔직히 말해서 지금은 엄청나게 많은 감독이 필요해요.

original.text: I was wearing heels all day, but I finally changed into some reasonable shoes for the walk home.

examples: I haven't seen a woman in this office wear sneakers in five years.
Am I allowed to wear sneakers to the office?
sentences.notes: changed into: ~으로 갈아입다/갈아 신다. reasonable shoes: 적절한/편안한 신발.
sentences.translation: 하루 종일 하이힐을 신고 있었지만, 집에 걸어가기 위해 드디어 편한 신발로 갈아 신었어요.

original.text: I'm secure in my sense of style, so I dress the way I like without worrying about others' opinions.

examples: She felt secure in her decision to change careers.
I sometimes feel insecure when I'm speaking English because I know I'm making a lot of mistakes.
Sometimes I feel insecure about asking for help at work.
sentences.notes: secure in: ~에 확신하는/자신 있는. feel insecure: 불안정하다고 느끼다.
sentences.translation: 저는 제 스타일에 자신감이 있어서, 다른 사람들의 의견을 걱정하지 않고 제가 좋아하는 방식으로 옷을 입어요.

original.text: He's really nervous about the presentation, but he's trying to put on a front that he's totally confident.

sentences.notes: put on a front: 겉으로만 ~인 척하다, 허세를 부리다. totally confident: 완전히 확신하는.
sentences.translation: 그는 발표에 대해 정말 긴장하고 있지만, 완전히 자신감 있는 척(put on a front) 가장하려고 노력하고 있어요.

original.text: In Mount Druitt, there are a lot of social issues. There's a lot of cyclical poverty.

examples: There's a lot of generational welfare dependence, the kinds of things that we see manifesting in the classroom, in big behaviours for a whole variety of reasons.
sentences.notes: cyclical poverty: 대물림되는 빈곤. generational welfare dependence: 세대 간 복지 의존. manifest in: ~에서 나타나다. big behaviours: 큰 문제 행동. whole variety of reasons: 아주 다양한 이유.
sentences.translation: 마운트 드루이트에는 많은 사회 문제가 있습니다. 순환적인 빈곤이 많습니다.

original.text: I had no friggin clue, zero clue on how to handle any of the behaviours already that were happening in this classroom, let alone a student with these complex needs.

sentences.notes: no friggin clue / zero clue: 전혀 모르다, 단서가 없다. let alone: ~은 물론이고, 하물며 ~은. (뒤에 오는 것이 더욱 불가능함을 강조)
sentences.translation: 저는 이미 이 교실에서 일어나고 있던 어떤 행동도 어떻게 다룰지 정말 아무런 단서도, 0의 단서도 없었는데, 하물며 이런 복잡한 요구를 가진 학생은 더더욱이요.

original.text: Being generous comes back to you.

sentences.notes: being generous: 관대함. comes back to you: (한 행동의 결과가) 자신에게 되돌아오다.
sentences.translation: 관대하게 행동하는 것은 당신에게 되돌아옵니다.

original.text: Actually, we went to a farmer's market a few weekends ago and just parked nearby, and we got sideswiped.

examples: Some car came and just swiped the side of our car. $2,000 in repairs.
sentences.notes: farmer's market: 농산물 직거래 장터. get sideswiped / swipe the side of our car: (차가) 측면 충돌을 당하다.
sentences.translation: 사실 몇 주 전에 파머스 마켓에 갔다가 근처에 주차했는데, 저희 차가 측면 충돌을 당했어요.

original.text: He's going to be so bummed when he finds out they finished the pizza without him.

examples: She's been bummed out all morning because of the bad news.
Yes, I'm super bummed she's moving. She just accepted a job there. Oh, that's so far.
sentences.notes: bummed / bummed out / super bummed: 실망한, 기분이 안 좋은.
sentences.translation: 자기를 빼고 피자를 다 먹어버린 것을 알게 되면 그는 매우 실망할 거예요.

original.text: I'm really happy this happened for her.

examples: She's been looking for a fresh start.
sentences.notes: happen for someone: ~에게 좋은 일이 생기다. fresh start: 새로운 시작.
sentences.translation: 그녀에게 이런 일이 생겨서 정말 기뻐요.

original.text: Even after the controversial verdict, the defendant exhibited dignity and thanked the court for its time.

examples: Throughout his final speech, the retiring CEO exhibited dignity, focusing on the company's future rather than past achievements.
sentences.notes: controversial verdict: 논란이 많은 평결. exhibited dignity: 품위를 보여주었다. throughout: ~내내. focusing on ~ rather than: ~보다는 ~에 집중하며.
sentences.translation: 논란이 많은 평결 후에도 피고는 품위를 보여주었고 법원에 시간을 내어준 것에 감사했습니다.

original.text: I grew up in the country/city, in Canada.

sentences.notes: grow up in the country/city: 시골/도시에서 자라다.
sentences.translation: 저는 캐나다의 시골/도시에서 자랐어요.

original.text: If you're a prospective buyer, you got a couple kids, want to turn it into your family compound.

examples: Do you see anything that might dissuade you from buying it? (디스웨이쥬 / ~하는 것을 단념시키다)
We are looking at the prospective costs of the project before we commit to it.
sentences.notes: prospective buyer: 장래의 구매자. turn into: ~으로 바꾸다. family compound: 가족 거주지/집단 거주지. dissuade from: ~하는 것을 단념시키다. prospective costs: 예상 비용.
sentences.translation: 만약 당신이 장래의 구매자이고, 아이들이 있고, 이것을 당신의 가족 거주지로 바꾸고 싶다면.

original.text: Yeah, I think, not even for just a family but for anyone, it's the lack of privacy happening.

sentences.notes: lack of privacy: 사생활 부족.
sentences.translation: 네, 가족뿐만 아니라 누구에게든, 일어나고 있는 사생활 부족 문제라고 생각해요.

original.text: There's something I'll put on your plate, important to me and this property.

examples: The privacy issue needs to be remedied through landscaping. I'll put you in charge.
Look over the proposal, make sure it blocks all of this street.
I have nothing on my plate.
sentences.notes: put on your plate: ~에게 (책임지고 처리할) 일을 맡기다. nothing on my plate: 할 일이 없다. remedy through landscaping: 조경을 통해 해결하다. put someone in charge: ~에게 책임을 맡기다. block: 가리다, 차단하다.
sentences.translation: 제가 당신에게 맡길 일이 하나 있는데, 저와 이 부동산에 중요합니다.

original.text: The landscaping here is particularly important.

examples: Every house it is, but this house in particular.
sentences.notes: particularly important: 특히 중요한. in particular: 특히.
sentences.translation: 여기 조경은 특히 중요합니다.

original.text: I'm gonna show you downstairs. Don't trip on this wire. Watch your head here.

examples: I don't have to, but you have to. Haha
sentences.notes: trip on: ~에 걸려 넘어지다. Watch your head: 머리 조심하세요.
sentences.translation: 아래층을 보여드릴게요. 이 전선에 걸려 넘어지지 않도록 조심하세요. 여기 머리 조심하세요.

original.text: Now, all I need is for my phone to be dead when I finally find it.

examples: Great, I'm already ten minutes late.
sentences.notes: All I need is for [something bad] to happen: (비꼬는 표현) 안 좋은 일이 일어나면 완벽하겠다.
sentences.translation: 이제 폰만 방전되어 있으면 딱이네.

original.text: Did you see anything strange at all?

sentences.notes: strange at all: 조금이라도 이상한.
sentences.translation: 조금이라도 이상한 것을 보셨나요?

original.text: I was already near the supermarket, so I figured I might as well grab the groceries while I was out.

examples: I couldn't find a parking spot close to the entrance, so I figured I might as well just park way in the back where there were plenty of open spaces.
sentences.notes: figure I might as well + 동사: ~하는 김에 그냥 ~하는 것이 낫겠다고 생각하다.
sentences.translation: 이미 슈퍼마켓 근처에 있었기 때문에, 외출한 김에 그냥 식료품을 사는 게 낫겠다고 생각했어요.

original.text: When you're traveling, sometimes it's best to just give in to the vibes of the city and see where the day takes you.

examples: I was going to leave early, but the music was so good I decided to give in to the vibes and stay until closing.
sentences.notes: give in to the vibes: 분위기에 순응하다/몸을 맡기다. see where the day takes you: 하루가 흘러가는 대로 가다.
sentences.translation: 여행할 때는 때때로 도시의 분위기에 몸을 맡기고(give in to the vibes) 하루가 당신을 어디로 이끄는지(where the day takes you) 보는 것이 최선일 때도 있어요.

original.text: That couldn't have been easy for you to handle all that pressure alone.

examples: I heard about your move; packing up your whole apartment on such short notice couldn't have been easy.
sentences.notes: couldn't have been easy: 쉽지 않았을 것이다. (과거에 대한 추측)
sentences.translation: 그 모든 압박을 혼자 감당하는 것이 당신에게 쉽지 않았을 거예요.

original.text: When the new policy was announced, many employees were left scratching their heads about how it would actually be implemented.

examples: The mechanic was scratching his head trying to figure out what was wrong with the car's engine.
sentences.notes: be left scratching one's head: 어찌할 바를 모르다, 혼란스러워하다.
sentences.translation: 새로운 정책이 발표되었을 때, 많은 직원들은 그것이 실제로 어떻게 시행될지 몰라 머리를 긁적였습니다.

original.text: The thing that really sucks/stinks is that the vacation was canceled at the last minute.

examples: The thing that really pees me off is having to wait on hold for an hour.
The thing that is really unfair is that only the managers got bonuses this year.
sentences.notes: The thing that really sucks/stinks/pees me off is that: 정말 짜증나는/불공평한 것은 ~이다. at the last minute: 막판에, 직전에.
sentences.translation: 정말 짜증나는 것은 휴가가 막판에 취소되었다는 것입니다.

original.text: She did most of the work, but her boss got all the credit for the successful presentation.

examples: Don't worry, you'll get credit for helping me move all these boxes.
He wanted to make sure his assistant got any credit for finding the critical data.
sentences.notes: get credit for: ~에 대한 공로를 인정받다. (긍정/부정 모두 사용 가능)
sentences.translation: 그녀가 일 대부분을 했지만, 상사가 성공적인 발표에 대한 모든 공로를 가져갔습니다.

original.text: He dismissed the first two suspects, so that leaves the third person as the only possibility.

examples: The restaurant is closed, so that leaves us with (eating) frozen pizza.
Since the restaurant is closed, that leaves us with (eating) frozen pizza.
We ruled out the first two ideas, which means we have to go with the last one.
We've considered everything, it just comes down to who is willing to pay the most.
sentences.notes: that leaves (someone) with (something): 그 결과 ~가 남다. rule out: 제외하다. go with: ~을 선택하다. come down to: 결국 ~로 귀결되다.
sentences.translation: 그는 처음 두 용의자를 기각했으므로, 그래서 세 번째 사람만이 유일한 가능성으로 남았습니다. (그래서 ~만이 남았다)

original.text: The students were scrambling for the last few spots in the popular elective course.

examples: When the fire alarm went off, people were scrambling for the exits.
sentences.notes: scramble for: ~을 차지하기 위해 다투다, 허둥지둥하다.
sentences.translation: 학생들은 인기 있는 선택 과목의 마지막 몇 자리를 차지하기 위해 서로 다투고 있었습니다.

original.text: The best I can figure is that he left the office around 3 PM yesterday, based on the security footage.

examples: The best I can figure
sentences.notes: the best I can figure: 내가 짐작할 수 있는 한, 내가 생각하기로는.
sentences.translation: 제가 추측할 수 있는 한, 보안 영상에 따르면 그는 어제 오후 3시경에 사무실을 나섰습니다.

original.text: The manager is tight with the owner, so be careful what you say around him.

examples: My uncle is really tight with money; he never buys anyone gifts.
sentences.notes: tight with: ~와 친한. tight with money: 돈에 인색한.
sentences.translation: 매니저가 사장과 친하니, 그 주변에서는 말조심하세요.

original.text: I haven't been applying myself enough to my fitness goals lately, so I need to step it up.

examples: We have to step up production this month if we want to meet the holiday demand. (더많이)
The local community really stepped up when the families lost their homes in the fire, offering food and shelter. (책임지고/적극적으로 나서다)
sentences.notes: apply oneself to: ~에 전념하다, 집중하다. step up: (노력, 속도, 생산 등을) 높이다, 강화하다; 적극적으로 나서다.
sentences.translation: 요즘 운동 목표에 충분히 전념/집중하지 못하고 있어서, 더 열심히 해야 해요.

original.text: I can't stand waiting in long lines at the grocery store on the weekends.

examples: She can't stand the smell of cigarette smoke, so she always sits outside at the cafe.
The new policy states that the management will not stand for any kind of discrimination in the workplace.
What does the acronym U.N. actually stand for?
sentences.notes: can't stand: ~을 참을 수 없다, 몹시 싫어하다. not stand for: ~을 용납하지 않다. stand for: ~을 상징하다, 의미하다.
sentences.translation: 주말에 식료품점에서 긴 줄을 서서 기다리는 것을 참을 수 없어요.

original.text: They should be landing at the airport right about now.

examples: Right about now, I could really use a cup of coffee.
sentences.notes: right about now: 지금쯤. (시간을 추측하여 말할 때)
sentences.translation: 그들은 지금쯤 공항에 착륙하고 있을 거예요.
